tossups.question: One character in this short story comments that boulders in the distance are only dangerous if they fall on you. That man claims that the people he employs prefer lashings over fines, asking “Which would you rather do? Take a good birching or lose your pay?” This short story begins with characters drinking and “pretending that nothing had happened.” It ends with a man sarcastically saying “Please is much better. Now I’ll stop” after asking a woman why she hadn’t poisoned her husband instead because “That’s what they do in England.” One character in this story dreams of the (*) animal he failed to kill while hunting, leading to his wife calling him a coward and sleeping with the hunter Robert Wilson. For 10 points, name this short story named after a man killed by his wife Margot on a big-game safari, a work by Ernest Hemingway.
tossups.answer: “The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber”

tossups.question: This myth system contains three magical birds or “Adar” whose song was used to comfort two different figures who were facing imminent death. One man in this system was cursed to never marry a human wife, so a woman of flowers is created for him, although she later arranges his death and is turned into an owl as punishment. In this myth system, a dead man’s head talks entertainingly for seven years and is then buried in a (*) hill to protect his land from invasion. In one tale from this country, terrified handmaidens frame their mistress for infanticide by smearing puppy blood onto her face. This country produced myths about Bran the Blessed, whose narrative was collected in one of the four branches of this country’s main mythological text. For 10 points, name this modern country that produced the Mabinogion, which contains stories of figures such as Blodeuwedd and Rhiannon.
tossups.answer: Wales [accept Cymru (“kum-ree”) or Welsh; prompt on the United Kingdom; prompt on Britain] (Blodeuwedd’s husband and eventual victim was Lleu Llaw Gyffes.)

tossups.question: Raymond Walters’ analysis on the origins of this institution credits a syndicate including David Parish and Jacob Barker with driving its creation. Ralph Catterall praised Langdon Cheves’ unpopular conservative leadership for saving this institution from collapse. In its only formal presidential censure, the Senate censured the President for firing William Duane for his refusal to sabotage this institution. An iconic political cartoon satirizes this institution as a (*) “many headed monster” being slain by the President. John Marshall concluded that “the power to tax [this institution] is the power to destroy [it]” while affirming its constitutionality in McCulloch v. Maryland. This institution induced a recession by contracting credit at the direction of Nicholas Biddle. For ten points, name this financial institution which names a “war” fought against it by Andrew Jackson.
tossups.answer: The Second Bank of the United States [or the Second BUS; prompt on the Bank of the United States; prompt on BUS; do not accept or prompt on “the First Bank of the United States”]

tossups.question: A series of proteins that assemble this structure are encoded by the p arms of acrocentric chromosomes; those proteins are RNR1 through 5. A treacle protein that is active within this structure is defective in individuals with Treacher Collins Syndrome. The tumor suppressor protein VHL becomes sequestered in this structure under hypoxic conditions in tumors. This structure consists of a granular component, a dense fibrillar component, and the fibrillar center. snoRNAs are found (*) exclusively in this structure, where they engage in methylation and pseudouridylation (“SOO-do-YUR-ih-dil-ATION”) of newly-transcribed rRNA. The 40S and 60S subunits are assembled in, for 10 points, what site of ribosome biogenesis, a membraneless organelle within the nucleus?
tossups.answer: nucleolus [do not accept or prompt on “nucleus,” ask them to spell if necessary]

tossups.question: In a concerto by this composer, the soloist begins the second theme of the first movement with a leap from A up to a held F-sharp, followed by a descending (read slowly) E - D - B, then a leap back up to D. In this composer’s final symphony, the last movement begins with the strings playing an ascending minor second that gets faster each time it repeats. This composer arranged a piano duet into the piece Klid, or Silent Woods, for cello and orchestra, and wrote a setting of (*) Stabat Mater after the death of his daughter. The fourth movement of his last symphony is marked allegro con fuoco, and the song “Goin’ Home” was based on an English horn solo in that piece. This composer’s Opus 104 is a cello concerto in B minor. For 10 points, name this Czech composer who denied that he quoted Native American tunes in his ninth symphony, called “From the New World.”
tossups.answer: Antonín Dvořák (“di-VOR-zhahk”)

tossups.question: The British seized supposedly uncultivated land from this modern-day country’s peasantry in the Wastelands Ordinance. The descendants of unions between Europeans and local women in this country form the Burgher ethnicity. A kingdom in this modern-day country fell under Portuguese influence after three sons of Vijayabahu VI murdered him and divided the kingdom between themselves. Chieftains joined the (*) Uva rebellion in this country two years after deposing King Vikrama Rajasinha in favor of the British in the Kandyan Convention. The Pali Canon was put to writing for the first time during the Fourth Buddhist Council in this modern-day country, which houses the Temple of the Tooth. The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam fought a 26-year insurgency against this country’s Sinhala majority. For 10 points, name this island country located just southeast of India.
tossups.answer: Sri Lanka [or Ceylon]

tossups.question: An alloy of this element’s telluride and cadmium telluride is used as a gamma ray sensor. A thermochemical cycle between this element and its oxide is used to produce hydrogen. An inherited or acquired inability to absorb this element causes acrodermatitis enteropathica. Six equivalents of this element are used in the Marsh test to detect arsenic. A couple of copper and this element is used to form (*) cyclopropane rings in the Simmons-Smith reaction. This element has a standard reduction potential of negative 0.76V. Ions of this element are bonded to residues of cysteine and histidine, its namesake finger domains. This element is coated onto steel in galvanization. For 10 points, name this element which is alloyed with copper to form brass.
tossups.answer: zinc [or Zn]

tossups.question: In The Two Babylons, Alexander Hislop conjectured that the Catholic theology was inspired by Babylonian religion founded by this man and his mother and consort Semiramis. Though not mentioned by name in the Quran, Islamic narratives connect this man with a figure who states “I give life and death” during a conversation with a prophet who asks him to raise the sun from the west. That prophet, Ibrahim, is nearly killed when this man catapults him into a fire. Assyria is called the land of this son of Cush, (*) who is described as a “mighty hunter before the Lord”. This man’s most famous accomplishment was said to reside in the land of Shinar and was hindered by God who made people speak different languages. For 10 points, identify this ruler who built the Tower of Babel and whose name is now a pejorative meaning stupid.
tossups.answer: Nimrod

tossups.question: Robert Bezeau built an entire village made of plastic bottles in this country. The Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute is located on this country’s Causeway Islands, where this country explores its natural history in the Frank Gehry-designed Biomuseo (“BEE-oh-moo-SAY-oh”). A World Heritage Site protects the biodiversity of the Gulf of Chiriquí in this country’s Coiba National Park, and major destinations include the Bocas del Toro archipelago. The Ciudad del Saber (“syoo-DAHD del sa-BER”) in this country is located on the (*) formerly-American Fort Clayton, which overlooks Lake Miraflores. The only break in the Pan-American Highway can be found at the Darién Gap in this country, where the damming of the Chagres River created Gatun Lake. For 10 points, name this country whose namesake canal connects the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.
tossups.answer: Panama

tossups.question: Before this event, one character says that the Great Bear is his favorite star, and this event causes a steward and his sons to come running. Directly after this event, the narrator remarks that one character was "unable to accompany them" and another character's "life was despaired of." Before this event, a character reads a poem ending "his eye shall seek me in the field around, but he shall not find me." A response accusing Nicolai of defecating on that character's grave resulted from a parody of this event involving (*) chicken blood. This event allegedly spawned many imitations by youths in yellow trousers and blue pants. A man who reads his lover a translation of Ossian takes this action with two pistols out of despair that Albert married Charlotte. For 10 points, name this climactic event of a Goethe novel about the "Sorrows" of its "Young" protagonist.
tossups.answer: the suicide of Werther [or the death of Werther]

tossups.question: Each of these things can be represented as a tuple of d-sub-n’s in the Lehmer code. The maximal subgroup of a group of these things can be classified using the O’Nan-Scott theorem. A group of these things is called oligomorphic if they only generate finite orbits when acting on cartesian products of a set S. Groups of these things that don’t preserve non-trivial partitions are called primitive. Alternating groups only contain even ones, while the (*) symmetric group of order n contains all of them on n elements. For a finite set, these things can be decomposed into transpositions. For a set of size n, there exist n factorial of them. For 10 points, name these bijections from a set onto itself that changes the order of elements, often contrasted with combinations.
tossups.answer: permutations

tossups.question: James Aronson of Case Western University led one of the initial attempts to use potassium argon radiometric dating to determine the age of this specimen. Marc Meyer discovered that a bone in this specimen's vertebral column originated from an extinct baboon relative. The observed valgus knee of this specimen led researchers to conclude features of bipedalism were present. This specimen's left os coxa, limb bones, and worn wisdom teeth point to an age of between 12 and (*) 18 years at death. Archeologists Donald Johanson and Yves (“EVE”) Coppens were among those on the team responsible for discovering this specimen in Hadar, Ethiopia in 1974. For 10 points, name this Australopithecus afarensis specimen dated to 3.2 million years ago, which is named after the title woman of a Beatles song.
tossups.answer: Lucy [or Dinkinesh; or Heelomali; prompt on AL 288-1; prompt on Australopithecus afarensis before mentioned]

tossups.question: Suetonius described a “duplex” form of this item known as the laena that was unique to flamens. According to legend, the wife of Cincinnatus fetched this item for him when emissaries of the Senate arrived. Mourners made use of the pulla variety of this item, which contrasted with the dazzling white (*) candida characteristic of public office-seekers. In later years, the stola became an analog of this item, which came to be associated with prostitution and adultery for women. Tullus Hostilius introduced the praetexta variety of this item for young males, which included a purple stripe to ward against evil magic. The solid purple picta form of these items was reserved for triumphant generals and eventually solely the emperor. For 10 points, name this garment usually consisting of white wool, traditionally worn over tunics by male Roman citizens.
tossups.answer: togas

tossups.question: Note to players: a general answer is acceptable. A painting set in this type of place was painted for an overdoor at the Bellevue chateau and is titled The Interrupted Sleep. Putti form a triangular composition in a painting set in this type of place that shows the title figure being taunted with a quiver while “a Captive.” A genre that used this type of place as its setting was developed by Nicholas Lancret and Jean-Baptiste Pater. This type of place was criticized for being “badly lit” by Francois (*) Boucher (“boo-SHAY”). Lavishly dressed aristocrats frolic in this type of place in the genre of the fete galante, which is meant to evoke the beauty of the mythological Arcadia. A painting set in this type of place depicts a young woman dressed in pink flinging off a pink slipper and sitting on the title object. For 10 points, Jean-Honore Fragonard’s The Swing, like many Rococo paintings, is set in what type of place?
tossups.answer: nature [or outdoors; or a garden; or a park; or a forest; or meadow; or an island; accept any answer implying an outdoor or lush setting]

tossups.question: In a two-level system, a plot of this quantity exhibits a peak, or “anomaly” named for Schottky. One approximation for it relies on letting the upper limit go to infinity in an integral over (read slowly) x to the fourth times e to the x all over quantity e to the x minus 1 squared. A model for this quantity which treats the system of interest as a collection of harmonic oscillators with the same frequency was developed by (*) Einstein, and successfully predicts that this quantity falls to zero at low temperature. This quantity equals three times the ideal gas constant for many materials according to the Dulong-Petit law. Two forms of this quantity, measured at constant pressure or constant volume, respectively equal the derivative of enthalpy or internal energy with respect to temperature. For 10 points, name this quantity which, for water, is 4.184 Joules per degree Celsius.
tossups.answer: heat capacity [or molar heat capacity or specific heat capacity]

tossups.question: This character’s father loses interest in sex, instead becoming fascinated with a plan to reclaim land through phallic concrete tetrapods. This character’s caretaker accidentally poisons him with a drug intending to give him “the lusty force of beasts.” He crashes his bicycle while trying to impress his air-pistol-toting childhood crush, and he predicts that on his 31st birthday 600 million people will crush him into “specks of voiceless dust.” After an air raid, this man (*) loses his memories, joins the army, and flees into the jungle where he is bitten by a snake. This character is given the nickname “Baldy” after his teacher tears out a patch of his hair, and he possesses “the most delicately-gifted olfactory organ in history.” For 10 points, name this telepathic character born on the night of India’s independence, the protagonist of Salman Rushdie’s Midnight’s Children.
tossups.answer: Saleem Sinai [prompt on Sinai]

tossups.question: This work calls E.L. Doctorow “the epic poet of the disappearance of the American radical past,” and borrows Lacan’s account of schizophrenia because it offers a “suggestive aesthetic model.” The introduction to this work characterizes its central concept as “an attempt to think the present historically in an age that has forgotten how to think historically in the first place.” This work discusses “the random cannibalization of all the styles of the past,” a phenomenon it calls (*) “pastiche.” This non-Heidegger work opens with a comparison between Van Gogh’s painting of peasant shoes and Diamond Dust Shoes by Warhol. This work calls its title concept “the cultural logic of late capitalism.” For 10 points, name this most famous work of Fredric Jameson, titled for a broad movement characterized by irony and self-referentiality.
tossups.answer: Postmodernism, or The Cultural Logic of Late Capitalism

tossups.question: In an aria in act 1, this character boasts that he can defy Argo’s hundred eyes if he fancies a girl, but concedes that if he loves one today, he’ll love another tomorrow. This character is based on Francis I in Victor Hugo’s play Le roi s’amuse, but the composer and librettist changed his name and background to get past censors. Near the start of act 3, this character sings an aria in 3/8 time in B major in which the last measure of the 8-bar melody is frequently left silent by the orchestra. He sings (*) “Questa o quella” in act 1, and secretly carries on an affair with his jester’s daughter. Gilda sacrifices herself to save this character from the assassin Sparafucile (“spa-ra-foo-chee-lay”), and Gilda’s father realizes that this character is still alive upon hearing him sing a reprise of his aria “La donna è mobile” (“MOH-bee-lay”). For ten points, name this tenor role from Verdi’s Rigoletto, who is referred to only by his title of nobility.
tossups.answer: The Duke of Mantua [or Il Duca di Mantova; prompt on Mantua or Mantova]

tossups.question: One collection by this writer states that a particular playwright could “now begin to assume the dignity of an ancient.” This writer opened that collection with the claim that the subject of his collection was “above all modern writers” in a preface that begins “That praises are without reason lavished on the dead.” This owner of the cat Hodge called Gaelic “the rude speech of a barbarous people” in one work. This writer of The Plays of William Shakespeare and A (*) Journey to the Western Islands of Scotland used the phrase “metaphysical poets” to classify the works of John Dryden in a collection of biographies and critiques. For 10 points, name this writer of Lives of the Most Eminent English Poets, who was biographied by James Boswell and wrote a Dictionary of the English Language.
tossups.answer: Samuel Johnson

tossups.question: Martin Chemitz evaluated the validity of traditions in an “examination” of this event while Leopold von Ranke wrote a book analyzing two opposing “histories” of it written by Sforza Pallavicino and Paolo Sarpi. This event is frequently divided into three chronological periods, the second of which was ended by Maurice of Saxony’s invasion of Tirol. This event’s start was delayed several years until the Treaty of Crépy helped resolve a dispute over support of the (*) Schmalkaldic League. The papal bull Benedictus Deus ratified decrees stemming from this event, which included reaffirming the seven sacraments, establishing the Tridentine Catechism, and rejecting the doctrine of sola fide. For 10 points, name this ecumenical gathering convened by the Catholic Church in 1545 as part of the Counter-Reformation.
tossups.answer: The Council of Trent [prompt on Counter-Reformation]

bonuses.leadin: In this poem, a husband complains to his wife, “A man can’t speak of his own child that’s dead” and ends by threatening her “I’ll follow and bring you back by force. I will!--” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poem consisting of a dialogue where a wife deplores her husband’s blase attitude during the title event.

“Home Burial” is by this poet, who created a dialogue between a husband and wife who stumble across a backwards-running river in “West-Running Brook” and a conversation between neighbors in “Mending Wall.”
This Frost poem, which is broken into segments like “Loneliness,” “House Fear,” and “The Impulse,” ends with a husband who “learned of finalities / besides the grave” after his bride ran away.

bonuses.leadin: Danes celebrate this holiday by lighting a bonfire with an effigy of a witch on top. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: St. John’s Eve [or Saint Jonas’ festival; or Sankthansaften]
parts: Identify this holiday in June often associated with the production of medicinal plants and the Midsummer. In Lithuania, people search for the magic fern blossom and worshipped Rasa prior to the Christianization of the Baltics.

Witches are a common theme in St. John’s Eve celebrations, exemplified by this Ukranian author who wrote about a witch appearing to Petro in a story titled for the holiday. He also wrote “The Nose” and “The Overcoat”.

People in this country celebrate St. John’s Eve by hitting their neighbors on the head with toy hammers and a leek. This country celebrates the dragon Coco by staging a fight between him and St. George during the Corpus Christi celebrations.

bonuses.leadin: This U(1) abelian gauge theory predicts virtual electron-positron pair production as the source of vacuum polarization. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this relativistic field theory of electromagnetism, developed by Schwinger, Tomonaga, and Feynman.
Applying perturbation theory to QED results in a power series of this quantity. This constant is equal to the ratio of the velocity of an electron in the Bohr model to the speed of light.
The fine structure constant is squared in this formula which gives the differential cross-section of high-energy photons in both Compton and Thomson scattering.

bonuses.leadin: George Maniakes (“man-EYE-uh-keez”) fought with mercenaries like William Iron Arm to secure this island from the Aghlabids. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this island later besieged by Roger Guiscard and his brother Robert to wrest control from the Muslim Kalbid Emirate.
Mercenary families like the Drengots and the Hautevilles that conquered southern Italy and Sicily belonged to this region, which William the Conqueror ruled and launched his invasion of England from.

The Hautville family ruled Sicily from their seat in the Palace of the Normans in this city. The Angevin rulers of Sicily were ousted after a rebellion beginning during the Vespers prayers in this city’s Church of the Holy Spirit.

bonuses.leadin: Although there is no evidence that he created it, this man lends his name to a mnemonic device that uses the parts of the hand to teach sight-singing. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this music theorist and author of Micrologus, who developed musical clef and staff notation, although his staves used only four lines.

Guido’s systems were used to learn this monophonic style of song, which was the mainstay of Catholic worship music in the middle ages. One type is named for Pope Gregory the Great, though he had nothing to do with its creation.
Gregorian chant usually employed this technique for shorter texts. It is defined as singing multiple notes on the same syllable.

bonuses.leadin: Drugs such as zidovudine and tenofovir target this virus’ reverse transcriptase. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this virus that causes AIDS.

Reverse transcriptase inhibitors and protease inhibitors are used to treat HIV, along with drugs like raltegravir, which inhibit this protein. This protein is responsible for inserting viral DNA into the host genome.

The drug Truvada, which is used for pre-exposure prophylaxis against HIV, consists of tenofovir and this other reverse transcriptase inhibitor, which is also found in the combination pills Descovy and Genvoya.

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher’s Tanner Lectures are collected in the 1996 book, The Sources of Normativity, and she argued that the awareness of the potential grounds of our beliefs is the source of reason in The Constitution of Agency. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this moral philosopher who currently teaches at Harvard.

Korsgaard is one of the most influential modern exponents of the work of this philosopher, who forms the main subject of her essays collected in Creating the Kingdom of Ends, a reference to this thinker’s categorical imperative.

Korsgaard’s paper Personal Identity and the Unity of Agency is a Kantian commentary on the Relation-R identity theory of this late British philosopher, who completed a long-standing project in ethics with the publication of his book On What Matters.

bonuses.leadin: One woman in this play is courted by a man whose name translates to omelet and a man who wants her to speak French, even though he doesn’t speak it. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Inspector General [or The Government Inspector; or Revizor]
parts: Name this play, the protagonist of which jumps out of a window to avoid the title event.
The final scene of this play includes an angry man, who was tricked by the title character, shouting “Who are you laughing at? Laugh at yourselves!” at the audience.
This Russian playwright wrote both Marriage and The Inspector General.

bonuses.leadin: Shamanistic laibons lead this monotheistic ethnic group’s worship of the god Engai. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Nilotic ethnic group whose boys undergo circumcision without anaesthetic in a rite of passage to achieve the status of moran, or warrior.

Two-thirds of the Maasai population of Tanzania died in the 1890s when an epidemic of this viral disease also known as cattle plague struck their cattle, which constitutes the primary source of Maasai wealth and food.
A debunked belief that Maasai pastoralism damaged savannah ranges led colonial British authorities to evict the Maasai from this Tanzanian national park famous for its wildebeest migration.

bonuses.leadin: Along with his biography of Bernini, the Vasari-wannabe Filippo Baldinucci is best known for a dictionary of artists that begins with this artist. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Cimabue (“chee-mah-BOO-ay”) [or Cenni di Pepi; or Cenno di Pepi]
parts: Vasari himself began Part 2 of his Lives with what artist? Vasari said a student of this artist eclipsed this artist’s crude Byzantine-inspired “maniera greca.”
That pupil of Cimabue was this Proto-Renaissance artist and circle-drawing enthusiast, who created fresco cycles depicting the Life of the Virgin and the Life of Christ for the Arena Chapel in Padua.

The Arena Chapel sets this scene on a barren slope above which several angels fly. This scene, depicted in Mantegna’s The Dead Christ, shares some overlap with the Pieta but includes more mourners at Mary’s side.

bonuses.leadin: Similar to magnetorheological fluids, this material’s viscosity can be tuned by an external magnetic field. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these materials that exhibit superparamagnetism. These materials typically consist of iron containing nanoparticles suspended in a carrier.
To prevent prevent clumping, ferromagnetic nanoparticles are typically coated in one of these substances that lowers the surface tension between liquids and solids.

A popular way to synthesize ferrofluids is by precipitating nanoparticles of this iron oxide compound in aqueous ammonia. This ferrimagnetic [sic] compound is the most magnetic naturally occurring mineral.

bonuses.leadin: A study led by researchers with this surname was re-examined in a PBS special that was controversial for showing high schoolers using sexual profanity. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Lynd [accept Robert Staughton Lynd or Helen Merrell Lynd]
parts: Give this surname of sociologists who ran a study that labeled one group as "the X family" and ended a second study by claiming that it would be easy for a dictator to gain sway over the title place.

Robert and Helen Lynd most famously gave this nickname to anthropological studies in Muncie, Indiana representing the namesake "average American city" as a conservative place divided between a working and business class. That study was succeeded by a study called "[this nickname] in Transition," set after the Great Depression.

The second Middletown study was less impartial than the first, more openly condemning the city's business class by citing this economist, the author of "The Theory of the Leisure Class" who coined the term "conspicuous consumption."

bonuses.leadin: One of these poems is spoken by an onion which asserts “I stand in bed / shaggy somewhere beneath,” and states that it makes a woman’s eye wet. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Old English [or Anglo-Saxon; prompt on English]
wyrd (“wird”) [or wyrde] (The line is “Wrætlic is þes wealstan, wyrde gebræcon.”)
parts: Name this genre of poems, 95 of which are preserved in the Exeter Book. The subjects of these poems include a shield, dough, and an iceberg.
The Exeter Book is the longest surviving manuscript of poetry in this language, which was also used to write Beowulf.

The “elegies” of the Exeter Book, such as “The Wanderer,” explore this Anglo-Saxon concept, which is variously translated as “fate” or “personal destiny,” and the corresponding impermanence of earthly things. The first line of “The Ruin” claims that this thing broke the walls.

bonuses.leadin: Super Bowl Sunday is practically a national holiday in the US. For 10 points each, answer the following about some famous moments in Super Bowl history:
answers_sanitized: New York Giants [or NYG; prompt on New York; prompt on NY]
parts: With a little over a minute remaining in Super Bowl XLII (“forty-two”), David Tyree made a miraculous 32-yard catch against his helmet on a 3rd and 5, helping this team beat the then-undefeated Patriots.

The very next year, the Steelers won Super Bowl XLIII (“forty-three”) thanks to this wide receiver’s effort to keep both feet in bounds on the game-winning touchdown with 35 seconds left on the clock.

During Super Bowl XLIX’s (“forty-nine’s”) media day, this team’s running back Marshawn Lynch made the phrase “I’m just here so I don’t get fined” iconic. This NFC West team saw their dream of back-to-back championships end when Patriots cornerback Malcolm Butler intercepted Russell Wilson’s goal line pass.

bonuses.leadin: Hannah Wilke molded chewing gum into the shape of these things and attached them to her naked body in her series “S.O.S. Starification Object Series.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name these things that are often abstractly depicted in 39 “place settings” in a series found in the Brooklyn Museum that begins with the “Primordial Goddess.”
Those symbolic depictions of 39 “guests of honor” are part of The Dinner Party, a work by this American feminist artist.

The final “guest” in Chicago’s The Dinner Party is this American artist, known for her floral abstractions of female genitalia and her painting of a cow’s skull in front of a flag colored red, white, and blue.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about appearances of donkeys in the Bible, for 10 points each:
parts: After being tied up and handed over to the Philistines by his fellow Jews, what lover of Delilah killed  over 1000 with a donkey’s jawbone?
Identify the man who beat his donkey three times for not allowing him to follow the Moabites, saving him from an angel of God.

Jesus is depicted riding a donkey into Jerusalem in Matthew 21, but according to Luke 19:41 he performs this action while looking at Jerusalem known as Flevit super illam. After another instance of Jesus performing this action, Jews that were crowded around him remarked “See how he loved him!”

bonuses.leadin: The namesake of these machines showed that the halting problem for them is undecidable. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these theoretical models of computation that use a read-write head to modify an infinite tape. They are named for a British mathematician who cracked the Enigma code.

Every language L described by this adjective is recursive, meaning that a halting Turing machine M that accepts L exists. By definition, a deterministic finite automaton exists for every language described by this adjective.

Regular languages are closed under union, intersection, and this other operation described by an asterisk. Named for an American mathematician, this operation denotes repeating a string zero or more times.

bonuses.leadin: During its decline, the Ottoman Empire signed capitulations allowing European powers to protect their coreligionists in these communities. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these autonomous communities of the Ottoman Empire into which religious minorities were organized to be governed under their own faith’s laws.

Because of Turkish aversion to learning non-Muslim languages, many of these imperial translators were Greeks from the Orthodox millet. These translators became de facto diplomats by virtue of their familiarity with the West.
These elite slave soldiers of the Ottoman Empire were recruited from Christian millets in the Balkans through the devshirme (“dev-SHER-meh”) system.

bonuses.leadin: The narrator of this novel returns home to find that his family’s “glorious talisman” is no longer being grown. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: wine [or The Republic of Wine; or The Palm-Wine Drinkard]
parts: Name this five-volume novel in which the Shandong family owns a distillery and participates as resistance fighters in the Second Sino-Japanese War.
This Chinese author of Life and Death Are Wearing Me Out and The Garlic Ballads also wrote Red Sorghum.
In a Mo Yan novel named for The Republic of [this substance], Ding Gou’er investigates claims of rural cannibalism. An Amos Tutuola novel is named for a “Palm” [this substance] “Drinkard.”

bonuses.leadin: In this sect’s Peace Testimony, members “utterly deny all outward wars, and strife, and fightings with outward weapons.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this pacifist Christian sect founded by George Fox whose adherent William Penn founded Pennsylvania.

Some Quakers refused to use this American paper currency of the Revolutionary War because its use promoted a violent cause. This currency’s severe depreciation led to the phrase “not worth a [this currency].”
Despite his religious background, this “Fighting Quaker” led a successful guerrilla campaign in the war’s southern theater and faced off against Lord Cornwallis at Guilford Courthouse.
